Mestre José Veiga s/n Braga 4715-330 Portugal b School of Chemical Engineering, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Engineering Campus, 14300, Nibong Tebal, Penang, Malaysia School of Chemical Engineering Universiti Sains Malaysia Engineering Campus Nibong Tebal Penang 14300 Malaysia ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Kaolinite, the main mineral in raw kaolin clay (RK) was explored as catalyst support for dry methane reforming (DMR) to produce syngas. Due to the inactiveness of the RK, it was activated by 5 M HCl and 5 M NaOH to produce acid treated kaolinite (ATK) and base treated kaolinite (BTK) catalyst supports, respectively. Two types of Ni active metal was incorporated into the modified supports, the first was the conventional nickel nitrate salt, and the second, organometallic nickel precursor synthesized via oxalate ligand functionalization (OxLF) of nickel particles. All the synthesized catalysts were calcined at 700 or 800 °C to study the effect of thermal treatment. The characterization results showed that OxLF was able to restrict the loss of Ni during washing and filtering at the synthesis stage according to the XRF result. The BTK support summarily transformed into SOD zeolite. Furthermore, the BTK supported catalyst showed comparable higher basicity than the ATK supported, however, as calcination temperature increases, there is loss of basic sites in both ATK and BTK supported catalysts, increase in the Ni mean particle sizes, and decrease in the Ni dispersion which cumulatively reduced the reaction rates leading to lower syngas yield. Irrespective of the catalyst support type and the calcination temperature, the oxalate ligand functionalized catalyst showed the lowest Ni mean particle sizes, highest metal dispersion and their Ni2p3/2 peaks were observed to shift towards lower binding energy according to the XPS results signifying higher reducibility which was verified by H2-TPR. The most efficient catalysts was NiOx/BTK-700 with 21.85% and 28.49% yield of H2 and CO, respectively. It also has the highest activity stability after 20 h TOS. The results showed that kaolinite is a possible future catalyst support for DMR. Keywords Kaolin Acid treated kaolinite Base treated kaolinite Oxalate ligand functionalization Dry methane reforming 1 Introduction Greenhouse gases (CO2 and CH4) abatement and possible utilization are issues of current global concerns. Several efforts have been made (and still being made) in the capturing of these gases especially CO2 via different sequestration methods such as absorption into different liquid/aqueous media and adsorption unto different solid materials. Since the proliferation of these gases are continually on the increase, it is important to keep searching for technologies that can capture and utilize them. Current efforts at utilizing CO2 include hydrogenation into oxygenates such as methanol, ethanol, olefins, aromatics, formaldehyde and dimethyl ether. A major drawback of this process is thermodynamic limitation because the low reactivity and chemically inert CO2 require elevated reaction temperature above 240 °C to activate the CO2 molecules to react with H2. However, studies [1,2] have shown that while increasing reaction temperature facilitates the activation and conversion of CO2, the production of CO is selectively promoted over that of methanol due to the higher apparent activation energy and endothermic character of the reverse water–gas-shift reaction (Eq. 1). Furthermore, the highest conversion of CO2 irrespective of the catalyst system is usually below 30% due to equilibrium constraints [2–5] which is considered a challenge to the CO2 hydrogenation process development and economics. A more promising route to utilize CO2 is via dry methane reforming, DRM (Eq. 2) which is a process of replacing steam with CO2 gas in the conventional steam reforming of methane, SRM (Eq. 3). One of the interesting advantages of this process is that a very high percent conversion of both greenhouse gases to syngas can be safely achieved. In addition, the H2/CO ratio can also be controlled to suit the characteristics of feedstock for the final product (Fischer–Tropsch or methanol synthesis for instance) [6]. Although the new route requires higher temperature (700–900 °C) to activate both CO2 and CH4, the process is still worthwhile since almost complete conversion of the gases to useful multi-industrial feedstock is possible. (1) C O 2 + H 2 → CO + H 2 O , Δ H 298 k 0 = + 41.17 kJ .mo l − 1 (2) C O 2 + C H 4 → 2 CO + 2 H 2 , Δ H 298 k 0 = + 247 kJ .mo l − 1 (3) C H 4 + H 2 O → CO + 3 H 2 , Δ H 298 k 0 = + 207 kJ .mo l − 1 According to literature reports, current efforts towards CO2 capturing/conversion to syngas using DRM process showed that emphasis is on catalysis to minimize catalyst deactivation due to coke deposition, and possibly lower reaction temperature [7]. For example, Taherian et al. [8], reported a comparative study of ZrO2, Y2O3 and Sm2O3 promoted Ni/SBA-15 catalysts for performance evaluation in DMR, and their findings showed that Sm2O3 promoted catalyst showed excellent activity, stability and coke resistance, while Y2O3 promoted catalyst just illustrated good activity at high temperature. ZrO2 promoted catalyst did not show any modification in catalytic performance in comparison to un-promoted Ni/SBA-15. Furthermore, they concluded that carbon deposition can be minimized if Ni species are uniformly distributed on a support. Alipour et al., [9] reported the influence of alkaline earth metal oxides (MgO, CaO, and BaO) promoters on Ni/Al2O3 and their findings showed that although the addition of MgO, CaO, and BaO as promoter decreased the surface area of catalysts, the overall catalytic activity were enhanced with reduction in coke formation. The highest activity was observed for the MgO promoted catalyst, furthermore, they showed that the addition of MgO increased the reducibility of nickel catalyst and decreased the reduction temperature of NiO species. Similar observation was also reported in related studies where CoxNi1-xO supported on macroporous silica-alumina were precoated with MgO [10] and Ca/Ni/K(Na) catalysts [11]. Another interesting study [12] also found that among Silcalite-1, MCM-41 and delaminated zeolite ITQ-6 materials used as support for Ni particles, ITQ-6 support prepared with higher heterogeneity and defective surface exhibits the highest dispersion of very small nickel particles (<20 nm), and prevents the metal particles from sintering. Thus showing the best catalytic performances up to 30 h of reaction without from coke formation since the Ni particles were very well dispersed and strongly linked to the support. On the other hand, the Ni particles deposited on no-defective Silicalite-1 support surface were very big with high CH4 reforming activity that leads to a high amount of coke deposits, while MCM-41 support with intermediate defects exhibits smaller nickel particles and lower amount of coke deposition. Omoregbe et al., [13,14] reported influence of La2O3 and CeO2 as oxide promoters decreased carbon deposition and La-doped catalyst showed the highest resistance to carbon deposition due to its small NiO crystallite size and inhibiting the Ni particles sintering. So far, among the supports that have been studied for DRM, mesoporous supports such as MCM-41, SBA-16, meso-Al2O3, silica, other metal oxides like titanium and zirconium are commonly reported. However, these supports are prone to challenges that affect their application in large-scale commercial applications such as deactivation [15], undesirable formation of non-catalytic inactive spinels such as nickel aluminate especially at higher calcination temperature, metal sintering [3,16,17], and potential heavy-metal pollution to the environment [18]. In addition, the high cost of some catalyst metals and promoters such as Zr, La, Y, Sm, Pt and Ru has precluded their application in industrial processes. Thus, since it has been established that the most stringent challenge in designing better DRM catalysts is the generation of small Ni(0) nanoparticles without losing the nickel into the support. Thus, the search for a cheap, environmentally friendly and high stable catalyst becomes imminent and imperative. One material that succinctly fits into this definition, but that has not been explored is kaolin clay which has certain amount of alkali and alkaline earth metals oxides such as Na2O, K2O, CaO and MgO [19] that can introduce in situ basic sites on the supported catalyst which is favorable for the CO2 activation. Typically, raw kaolin (RK) is a highly crystalline hydrated layered aluminosilicates with ratio 1:1 tetrahedron [SiO4]4− and octahedral [AlO4]5−, in which each oxygen of the tetrahedron is shared with the next tetrahedron, be it Al or Si [20]. The main mineral in the RK is kaolinite, however, there are also others such as quartz, mica and smectite [21]. RK is almost inactive (i.e. high passivity) since it is a naturally occurring mineral, thus it must be activated via chemical (acid or base), thermal or mechanical treatments, or combination of any two prior to use as catalyst support in order to provide the necessary anchoring sites for the incorporated active metal(s) to prevent leaching [21–23]. In addition, in order to achieve the generation of small Ni(0) nanoparticles without the nickel migrating into the support as mentioned above, the method of nickel precursor synthesis and incorporation into the support is very important. The common practice is to impregnate the alumina support with nickel salts in aqueous media, a synthesis protocol under which the Ni2+ ions react with a hydrated alumina surface to form the characteristic poorly reducible hydrotalcite phase after calcination [6]. This challenge can be mitigated by employing Ni precursor with organic functionalization via surface organometallic chemistry (SOMC) which has emerged as a powerful approach to generate single site catalysts [24]. Previous studies [25,26] showed that active metal (Co and Ni) precursors that were synthesized via organometallic functionalization route possessed very small Co/Ni nanoparticles with higher dispersion, reducibility and stability leading to superior activities compared to others prepared via conventional routes. In this present contribution, we explore the applicability of RK as a catalyst support for different Ni active metal precursors. In order to employ the RK as an effective support, it was activated by either acid, 5 M HCl or base, 5 M NaOH in order not to damage the kaolinite structure. Furthermore, two different Ni precursors – convectional aqueous nickel nitrate salt and organic ligand functionalized Ni were incorporated into the both acid activated kaolin and base activated kaolin. The developed catalysts were calcined at two different temperatures (700 °C and 800 °C), and extensively characterized to study the effect of the synthesis protocol on their structure and reactivity in DMR in a fixed bed continuous flow reactor. For effective analysis, the catalysts activity was reported in terms of rate of CO2 and CH4 reaction, while the products were reported in yield. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Nickel nitrate hexahydrate, NaOH pellets, HCl (37% v/v) and anhydrous oxalic acid were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, while Kaolin powder was supplied by R&M marketing, Essex, UK Company with CAS number 1332-58-7. All materials were used without any pretreatment. Double distilled water was used throughout the experiment. 2.2 Catalyst development The catalyst synthesis protocol was achieved in two stages. In the first stage, the RK was either carefully activated by HCl or NaOH following our previously reported method [26]. In the acid activation step, 50.0 g of RK was added to a clean and oven dried round bottomed flask equipped with a reflux condenser. After that, 200 ml of 5 M HCl was gently added to round bottomed flask containing the RK sample and was treated for 2 h refluxing at 110 °C to activate the RK. The reaction was immediately quenched by adding iced water followed by filtration and repeated washing with distilled water to remove any unspent acid. The resulting solids were dried in an oven at 110 °C for 12 h and grinded to powder. Similar procedure was repeated for the base treated RK except that the NaOH was used in place of HCl. The acid and base treated supports were denoted as ATK and BTK, respectively. In the second stage, the nickel oxalate catalyst precursor was prepared by functionalizing 19.81 g nickel nitrate hexahydrate with oxalic acid (OA) in stoichiometric ratio (1:1) to yield the polynuclear nickel II oxalate complex (NiOx) in an aluminum foil wrapped conical flask since it has been reported that metal oxalate ligands have high photo sensitivity index [27]. The NiOx was subsequently incorporated into 40.0 g ATK or BTK dispersion (i.e. ATK/BTK dispersed in deionized water) and left stirring for 6 h at 50 °C to guarantee the exchange of their intergallery cations with NiOx particles and also deposition of NiOx particles on the ATK/BTK support. The resulting mixtures were filtered, dried in the oven at 100 °C, grinded and calcined at either 700 °C or 800 °C for 4 h in a muffle furnace followed by testing and characterization. The synthesized catalyst notation followed the order: active metal, type of support modification, and calcination temperature, e.g., Ni/ATK-800, Ni/BTK-800 and NiOx/BTK-700. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The XRF analyses of the samples were done to determine the chemical composition of the sample using a Philips Model-PW2400 and x-ray tube of rhodium anode and scintillation detector operating on a 40 mA current and 40 mV voltage. The samples were bombarded with high-energy x-rays and the x-ray reflections from the excited samples were detected by the scintillation detector, the detected spectra were amplified and recorded using the computer program installed on the XRF analyzer. Extreme high resolution field emission scanning electron microscope (XHR-FESEM) and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) were performed to determine the samples morphology and elemental composition, respectively using Verios XHR-FESEM (Model 460 L, FEI™) equipped with an EDS detector. The catalyst microstructure and crystallographic information were studied by high resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) 200 kV with Field Emission (TECNAI G2 20 S-TWIN, FEI™). The XRD patterns of the samples were measured with Philip PW 1820 diffractometer to determine the crystal phase and structure of the metal oxides earlier detected by XRF analysis. Diffraction patterns of the samples were recorded with Cu Kα radiation and recorded in the range of 5-90° (2 theta) with a scanning rate of 2°/min and a step size of 0.01°. The X-ray tube was operated at 40 kV and 120 mA. The reduction behavior and active metal dispersion of the catalysts was studied using a Thermo Finnigan TPDRO 1100 equipped with a thermal conductivity detector and a mass spectrometer. Typically, 20 mg catalyst was placed in the U-shaped quartz tube. Catalyst samples were degassed under a flow of nitrogen at 200 °C to remove traces of water and impurities from the catalyst pores. H2 temperature program reduction (TPR) was performed using 5% H2/N2 with a flow rate of 20 ml min−1 and heating from 40 to 990 °C at 5 °C min−1. XPS analyses (Thermo-Fischer K-Alpha) were carried out to obtain the chemical nature, surface composition, oxidation state, relative surface compositions and the type of interaction between metal and support. The XPS was equipped with monochromatised AlKα source and the resulting samples spectra were analyzed using the Avantage software for peak fitting and identification of chemical state. The XPS wide and narrow scan spectra were acquired using AXIS Ultra DLD, Kratos, equipped with a Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6 eV) at 10 mA, 15 kV, analyzing a 300μmm X 700 μm area under 4.3 × 10−9 torr ultra-vacuum environment inside sample analyze chamber. Using the multichannel plate and delay line detector (DLD). The analysis were performed in the hybrid lens mode with the slot aperture and the analyzer was operated in fixed analyzer transmission(FAT) mode with pass energy of the hemispherical analyzer was set at 160 eV for the survey/wide scan and 20 eV for the high resolution scans/narrow scans, while minimum time of scanning was 10 times. The spectra were analyzed using the Avantage software for peak fitting and identification of chemical state. The linear method was used for background subtraction and curve fitting. Binding energy was referenced to an adventitious carbon at 284.6 eV. The basicity test was carried using temperature programmed desorption (TPD-CO2) in a Thermo Finnigan (model TPDRO 1100 series). The sample was pretreated under the flow N2 gas (30 ml/min) at 150 °C for 40 min, followed by adsorption with CO2 gas for 60 min at room condition. The excess of CO2 were subsequently flushed out by flowing N2 gas prior to the analysis. The desorption of the CO2 from the basic sites of the catalyst were identified by TCD under helium gas (30 ml min-1) ranging from 50 °C C to 900 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. 2.4 Catalyst testing The DRM activities of the different catalyst were performed in a laboratory-scale fixed bed stainless steel reactor. In each test, 0.2 g of the catalyst was carefully loaded on a quartz wool that was placed in the fixed-bed tubular reactor (ID: 10 mm and length: 35 cm) that was vertically positioned in a split-tube furnace. The temperature of the catalyst bed was monitored using a type-K thermocouple. The catalyst was reduced in-situ in a flow of 50 ml min−1 of H2/N2 (1:5) for 1 h at 700 °C, followed by purging with 50 ml/min of N2 flow for 20 min prior to the reaction. The activity of the catalysts were studied at 700 °C with CH4: CO2 = 1.0. All the gas flows were monitored by Alicat digital mass flow controllers, with the overall gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) fixed at 30 000 h−1. The compositions of the unreacted reactants (CH4 and CO2) and the products (H2 and CO) were measured by online gas chromatography instrument (Agilent GC system 6890 N Series) equipped with thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The GC system consists of two packed columns, Supelco Molecular Sieve 13 x (10 ft x 1/8 in OD x 2 mm ID, 60/80 mesh, Stainless Steel) and Agilent Hayesep DB (30 ft x 1/8 in OD x 2 mm ID, 100/120 mesh, Stainless Steel). The carrier gas was helium gas at a flowrate of 20 ml min−1 and the operating column temperature is 393 K. The reactant feed gas conversion, syngas ratio (H2/CO), products yield and rate of reaction for the reactant gases are defined according to Eqs. 1–6. The averages values of two experimental runs were recorded and plotted. The chemical composition of RK shared close similarities with those of natural Spanish kaolin from the Navalacruz deposit in the Zamora province of Spain [21] but a staggered departure from those of other commonly reported kaolin such as from Kolkata, India [28]. After the acid treatment to activate the support, there is obvious increase in the Si/Al ratio from 1.06 in RK to 1.75 in ATK due to de-alumination of RK which can be described by Eq. 7. Typically, acid activation leaches clays mineral causing disaggregation of clay particles, elimination of mineral impurities, and dissolution of the external layers, thus altering the chemical composition and the structure of the clays [21]. According to the author’s previous report [23], this alteration has been observed to enhance the surface area, porosity, and the number of acid centers with increased catalytic activity when compared to the parent clays, and such enhancement depends on the intensity of the treatment. There is no signal of Na in the XRF of ATK and Ni/ATK-800 (Table 1) due to the acid treatment that produced easily-wash-off soluble NaCl salt (Eq. 8). Same explanation goes for Eq. 7 since AlCl3 is very soluble like NaCl. On the other hand, the composition of Na2O increased in Ni/BTK-800 and NiOx/BTK-800 catalysts due to the incorporation of Na during NaOH treatment. The amount of NiO is higher in NiOx/ATK-800 and NiOx/BTK-800 than in Ni/ATK-800 and Ni/BTK-800 due to the oxalate ligand functionalization (OxLF) that restricted the wash-off of the incorporated Ni species during washing and filtration at the synthesis stage. (7) Al2O3·2SiO2·2H2O + 6HCl → 2AlCl3 + 2SiO2 + 5H2O + ½H2 (8) 2HCl + Na2O → NaCl + H2O The influence of acid and base treatment on the samples can also be seen in the morphology of the samples in Fig. 1 . Typical characteristics of kaolin morphology can be seen in Fig. 1a with stacks of irregular plates that appeared to have been formed by several flaky particles as clearly seen by the magnified image in Fig. 1b. This closely stacked arrangement can be seen to have loosen in Fig. 1c (ATK) after acid treatment which causes disaggregation and disorder in the stacked particles arrangement leading to increased porosity. The morphology BTK in Fig. 1d is completely different from those of RK and ATK, instead it conformed to somewhat semi-zeolitic crystals with very conspicuous reduction in the average particle sizes and distortion in particles arrangements. In fact, up to three levels of zeolitization can be safely distinguished as follows: the first were the primary kaolinite particles in the green dotted line oblong which were still retaining part of their original signatures after NaOH activation. The second were the small zeolitic spherical aggregates of thread-ball-like particles growth on the surfaces and edges of the stacks of irregular plates of the RK (in red rings), and lastly were those fully grown tertiary particles of quasi-spherical clusters (in blues rotated squares, Figure S1 demonstrated a clearer morphology). This morphology suggests the formation of sodalite zeolite (SOD) nanoparticles [29]. The morphology of Ni/ATK-800 in Fig. 1e does not show any significant variation from that of ATK except that there were dotted particles on the Ni metal that were deposited on the more loosen stacked arrangements of the irregular kaolinite plates. However, the image of Ni/BTK-800 in Fig. 1f showed an interestingly distinct spongy web-like morphology on the particles surfaces due to the interactions between the Ni precursor and the zeolitic surface of BTK with highly evident particle-edges-abrasion leading to reduction in particles sizes. Although there are still instances of preserved RK structures in the blue oblong ring, the Ni/BTK-800 particles appeared to be more crystalized conforming more to SOD zeolitic structure due to the dehydration of the sodalite Na6[AlSiO4]6∙8H2O at the calcination stage. Earlier report by Felsche et al., [30] had shown that the crystal structure of Na6[AlSiO4]6∙8H2O is strongly determined by hydrogen bonding (HB) between the non-framework hydrate water oxygens (donators) and the framework oxygens (acceptors), and this HB is destroyed in a two-step dehydratation reaction at 400–500 K to yield highly crystalized SOD framework. The morphology of NiOx/ATK-700 (Figure S2) showed a very porous, irregular flakes, these features becomes more intense in the NiOx/ATK-800 morphology (Fig. 1g) with needle-like flakes indicating structural deformation and disordered stacking of RK support. This phenomenon is linked to the protonic effect of the oxalic acid used to functionalize the Ni precursor at the synthesis stage which produced a partial dissolution of Al3+ cations from the octahedral sheet leading to relative increase in the Si/Al ratio seen in Table 1. The more intense phenomenon observed in the NiOx/ATK-800 morphology was ascribed to additional de-alumination of the catalyst under thermal treatment. It was recently shown that extra-framework Al could be removed by directly treating with hydrochloric acid, and framework Al could be removed by hydrothermal treatment [31]. The morphology of NiOx/BTK-800 (Fig. 1h) reflected considerable loss of crystallinity after the incorporation of the NiOx precursor and calcination leading to a highly amorphourized products due to the acidic influence of the NiOx when compared with Ni/BTK-800. The NiOx/BTK-800 morphology also somehow suggest instances of hydrotalcite formation (Figure S2). 3.1.2 Structural variation analysis – XRD and TEM The structural variations as a consequence of the acid and base treatment of the RK and subsequent incorporation of Ni precursors (Ni(NO3)2 and NiOx) were studied using X-ray diffraction technique and the diffractograms are shown in Fig. 2 . The RK shows clearly well-defined reflections at 2θ = 12.5° and 25° corresponding to the d values of 7.154 Å with [0 0 1] plane reflections and they are typical characteristic peaks of kaolinite [28]. Other kaolinite peaks with varying intensities can be seen at ranges 2θ = 20.0–23.4°, 34.8-40°, 45.8°, 55.5–60.0° and another conspicuous peak at 62.5°. After the acid treatment, the intensities of the kaolinite peaks drastically reduced except those at 12.5° and 25°, while the quartz peak also showed relative reduction due to the protonic effect that removed the extra-framework Al earlier seen in the XRF result. This variation in the peaks intensity confirmed the disaggregation and disorder in the stacked particles arrangement of the RK morphology (Fig. 1a,b) leading to a reduction in the Hinckley index from > 0.7 in RK to < 0.6 in ATK. As previously observed in the morphology of the BTK which showed a complete deviation from those of RK and ATK, its diffractogram can also been seen to have completely deviated from those of RK and ATK. Those kaolinite and quartz peaks had disappeared completely except a miniscule kaolinite peak at 2θ = 12.5° which is possibly reflecting the primary kaolinite particles in the oblong green dotted line (Fig. 1d) which were still partially retaining their original signatures after NaOH activation. The disappearance of those kaolinite and quartz peaks and the appearance of well crystallized peaks at 2θ = 14.2°, 24.4°, 31.7°, 34.7°, 43.3°, 52.2° and 58.3° in the BTK diffraction pattern confirmed the transformation of RK into SOD earlier suspected in the SEM image (Fig. 1d). This result guarantees a new and simplified protocol for the synthesis of SOD particles compared to present practice which involves multistage processing and the use of expensive structure directing agent [29,32,33]. After the incorporation of the Ni(NO3)2 and NiOx precursors into the ATK and BTK followed by calcination at 700 °C and 800 °C, different NiO peaks reflected at 2θ = 37.2, 43.3, 62.9 and 75.5 corresponding to (111), (200), (220) and (311), respectively according to JCPDS 47–1049 database [34]. These peaks were not seen in the non-functionalized catalysts – Ni/ATK-800 and Ni/BTK-800. Generally, nonappearance of diffraction peaks of incorporated metals into different supports have been observed in the literature and they were usually ascribed to one or more of the following as the case may be: (1) high metal dispersion of extremely low metal particle size, (2) covering of metal particles by support, (3) migration of the metal into the support, (4) formation of non-crystalline nanoparticles, and (5) formation of homogeneous non-reducible spinels like nickel- and cobalt-aluminate for NiO and CoO, respectively supported on alumina [6,25,35–37]. Based on the XRF result (Table 1) and the TEM images in Fig. 3 , it can be concluded that the nonappearances of Ni species peaks in Ni/ATK-800 and Ni/BTK-800 were due to low metal content, and independent of NiO particle size in this report. For example, the TEM image of Ni/ATK-800 showed larger average particle size of 22.7 nm while NiOx/ATK-700 showed 4.8 nm. As calcination temperature increased to 800 °C, the NiO particle size increased to 6.4 nm in NiOx/ATK-800 showing that there is agglomeration of particles at higher calcination temperature. One interesting feature in these catalysts is that those that were prepared via functionalization with organic oxalate ligand produces comparatively low NiO particle sizes. This implied that the synthesis protocol was able to guarantee spatial adsorption and anchoring of very small size nickel nano particles onto the modified support, thus mitigating the migration of nickel into the support which can lead to the formation of nonreducible NiO species. Similar observation was recently observed in a study of molecularly tailored nickel precursor and support, and the authors reported that deposition of the precursor using organic solvents produced nanoparticles with a decreased mean size [6]. The NiO peaks in NiOx/ATK-800 and NiOx/BTK-800 are more intense and crystalline than NiOx/ATK-700 in Fig. 2, which confirmed that there is NiO particle growth as calcination temperature increases. In fact, the low peak at plane (311) were not visible in NiOx/ATK-700, and it supported the observation of the NiO average particle size in the TEM image (Fig. 3). 3.1.3 Reducibility of supported NiO particles The profile and the evaluated data for the reducibility of all the samples conducted via temperature programmed reduction technique are shown in Fig. 4 and Table 2 , respectively. All the catalyst showed two reduction peaks which implied that NiO particles existed on those modified supports in two distinct states, (1) as free form NiO – Peak 1 and (2) as strongly bonded NiO on the surface/in the pores as well as presence of very small-sized particles – Peak 2. From the TPR profiles of these catalyst, it is obvious that the influence of acid/base treatment, OxLF and calcination temperature played very significant roles in the reduction patterns. The non-functionalized catalysts exhibited reduction peaks at higher temperature, which implied that there is strong metal-support-interaction (MSI). The Ni/ATK-800 catalyst showed the highest MSI with only 11.42% reduction of NiO at lower reduction temperature of 445 °C and substantial reduction of 88.58% reduction taking place at higher reduction temperature of 607 °C (Table S1). Similar observation is seen in the profile of Ni/BTK-800 except that its Peak 1 even shifted to higher temperature at 467 °C with 42.64% NiO reduction which confirmed that there is a chemical modification between the Ni species and the SOD zeolitic structure seen the in the BTK morphology. The Ni/BTK-800 Peak 2 with maximum at 571 °C and 57.36% reduction of NiO is highly broad which suggested increased difficulty in the reduction of NiO species that have chemically interacted with the tetrahedrally coordinated sites (TCS) of Al2O3 component in the BTK support. From the XRF data, the amount of Al2O3 were observed to be lower in ATK than BTK due to influence of acid leaching, and this supports why the amount of reduced nickel species chemically interacting with the TCS of Al2O3 is higher in Ni/BTK-800 than in Ni/ATK-800. Typically, these nickel species chemically interacting with TCS of Al2O3 are not readily reducible at temperatures below 400 °C [38]. Both reduction Peaks 1 and 2 shifted to lower reduction temperature in the oxalate ligand (OxL) functionalized catalyst which suggested a weaker MSI. One of the factors that favored the shifting of these peaks to lower temperature is the comparative high amount of nickel species (XRF result) since it has been established that the rate of reduction of nickel species does not only depends on its chemical nature (as mentioned above) but also on the nucleation process by which metallic nuclei are generated [38]. Thus, for high metal loading catalysts, a significant amount of reducible NiO species may serve as metallic nuclei to facilitate the reduction of the NiO species. Another interesting feature from the TPR profile is that the peaks intensities of the OxL functionalized catalysts were higher than the non-functionalized. This confirmed that the functionalized catalysts consumed more hydrogen in the reduction process. For example, Ni/BTK-800 and NiOx/BTK-800 achieved 33.7% and 51.9% reduction, respectively which is a reflection of the number of reduced metal surface in Table 2. As earlier observed in the TEM result and sufficiently supported by the mean particle diameter calculated by TPDR after reduction (Table 2), the functionalized catalysts exhibited comparably far smaller mean NiO particle sizes which increased their external surface area exposed to hydrogen consumption for reduction process. In addition, the functionalized catalysts according to the XRF result (Table 1) showed comparably higher amount of Ni species, while the non-functionalized showed lower amount as a result of Ni loss during catalyst washing/filtering at the synthesis stage. Thus, higher amount of NiO will consume more hydrogen gas for reduction. Calcination temperature can also be seen to have played key role both in the reduction temperature and the intensity of the peak. NiOx/ATK-800 consumed more hydrogen for reduction and the Peak 1 shifted towards higher reduction temperature when compared to NiOx/ATK-700 because higher calcination temperature increased the propensity of homogenizing the metal and the support. In any case, the absence of any peak at reduction temperature above 700 °C ruled out possibility of formation of spinel in agreement with the XRD results, and this showed that chemically modified kaolinite is a potential Ni support for DMR. 3.1.4 Surface chemistry via XPS The results of XPS analysis performed to determine the variations in the surface chemistry of three representative selected catalysts (Ni/BTK-800, NiOx/ATK-800 and NiOx/BTK-800) are shown in Fig. 5 . The Ni/BTK-800 catalyst showed the Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 peaks at 855.62 eV and 872.96 eV binding energies (BE), respectively with a BE split ΔENi (i.e. ΔENi = Ni 2p1/2 – Ni 2p3/2) of 17.04. Similarly, the NiOx/ATK-800 catalyst showed the Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 peaks at 855.23 eV and 873.20 eV BEs, respectively. When compared with the standard binding energy (BE) of pure NiO (854.2 eV) [39], the BE of oxidized Ni shifted positively by 1.42 eV and 1.03 eV for Ni/BTK-800 and NiOx/ATK-800, respectively toward higher BE showing higher extents of oxidation and very strong MSI [25]. The larger positive shift of Ni/BTK-800 was ascribed to the NaOH treatment that resulted into surface and structural reconstruction of the BTK support to form SOD zeolite (see SEM and XRD results) which generated oxo-Ni species, i.e. Ni(OH)2 and NiOOH phase because the Ni 2p3/2 of 855.62 eV observed for Ni/BTK-800 corresponds to the reported BE for Ni(OH)2 [40,41]. The Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 peaks shifted to lower BE of 853.10 eV and 870.61 eV, respectively in NiOx/BTK-800. This shifting of the Ni 2p3/2 to lower BE negatively by 0.9 eV showed that the Ni is poorly oxidized due to the C2O4– ligand functionalized at the synthesis stage. Ostensibly, this C2O4– ligand was also responsible for the comparably lower BE shift observed in NiOx/ATK-800 when compared with Ni/BTK-800. This phenomena is also confirmed by the TPR profile of Ni/BTK-800 (Fig. 4) with highly broad reduction Peak 2 which suggested increased difficulty in the reduction of oxidized Ni species that have chemically interacted with the components of the BTK support. Previous studies also showed, C2O4–, OxLF is highly beneficial at constraining electrooxidation of metals, minimize metal support interaction and guaranteeing high active metal dispersion [25,26]. The influence of the C2O4– ligand can be further elucidated by the deconvoluted spectra of C 1 s, O 1 s and Na 1 s in Fig. 6 . The C 1 s scan of Ni/BTK-800 has a CC peak at 284.52 eV and another small peak at 288.65 eV which are due to CC and CO from adventitious carbon. Both NiOx/ATK-800 and NiOx/BTK-800 showed wider peak base and increased full-width at half maximum (FWHM) due to the influence of the OxLF. These peaks were deconvoluted into two with BE at 285.05 eV and 288.83 eV for NiOx/ATK-800, and 285.02 eV and 288.25 eV for NiOx/BTK-800. In order to understand the origin of these peaks, it is important to note that according to the molecular structure of oxalic acid and nickel oxalate (Fig. 7 ) they contains two carboxyl group carbons and one CC, thus is expected to yield two C 1 s photoelectron peaks at binding energies around 288.9 eV (C2O4 2−) and 285 eV (CC/CH) with an intensity ratio of 2:1 [42]. However, since the catalysts were calcined at higher temperature, the decomposition of some C2O4 2− must have taken place to yield more CC which explains the increase in their FWHM and the slight shift to higher BE. A reverse trend of the ratio of area under the graph for BE 288.83 eV and 285.95 eV was observed for NiOx/BTK-800 (1:0.58) compared to Ni/BTK-800 (0.19:1) and NiOx/ATK-800 (0.35:1). The cause for this is not clearly known, but the reconstruction of the BTK into SOD and incorporation of NiOx might be responsible for developing some thermal resistance CO/CO carbon based species or hyrotalcites (HTs) observed in the SEM morphology of NiOx/BTK-800 (Figure S2). Recently it was reported that calcined HTs which are anionic clays that can be synthesized in the presence of Al salts, NaOH/KOH and metals (Zn, Ni, Cu, etc) nitrate salts are recognized as thermally stable [43]. The O 1 s of Ni/BTK-800 showed only one well resolved peak at 530.23 eV which was ascribed to metal-oxygen bond (e.g. NiO). Typical O 1 s peaks at 531.5 eV that is usually ascribed to adsorbed oxygen from moisture or structural water [25] does not appear in the O 1 s of Ni/BTK-800 due to high temperature at the calcination stage. However, both NiOx/ATK-800 and NiOx/BTK-800 showed additional O 1 s peak after deconvolution at higher BE of 534.11 eV and 534.16 eV, respectively and these peaks were ascribed to decomposition products of dicarboxylic acids according to previous report [42]. The peaks Area for these decomposition products of dicarboxylic acids were 6231.51 CPS∙eV and 3459.58 CPS∙eV for NiOx/ATK-800 and NiOx/BTK-800, similarly, the peaks intensities were 1794.53 and 1098.11, respectively. These showed that the extent of decomposition of the OxL is higher in NiOx/ATK-800, which supports the earlier suspicion that there could be formation of some thermally stable species e.g. HT. Both Ni/BTK-800 and NiOx/BTK-800 showed the presence of Na 1 s, however, while both of them gave Na 1 s peaks at 1066.20 eV and 1070.14 eV, and 1066.25 eV and 1070.69 eV which are due to Na ions interacting with carbon (C–Na) and peak for H–O–Na group, respectively [44] the BE of NiOx/BTK-800 at the second peak shifted by + 0.55 eV possibly due to the influence of OxA functionalization. Furthermore, it is important to note that NiOx/BTK-800 gave additional peak at higher BE of 1073.25 eV which could be ascribed to the sodium ions in ONa groups originating from the influence of OxA functionalization. 3.1.5 Catalysts basicity The catalyst basicity is an important factor that can enhance the adsorption of CO2 to the surface of the catalyst to initiate CO2 activation at the active site since CO2 is an acidic gas. The profiles of the catalysts basicity are shown in Fig. 8 , and the amounts of CO2 adsorbed and other relevant information are shown in Table S2. The Ni/BTK-700 has the highest amount of 1039.78 μmole/g for CO2 desorption at 168 and 689 °C (for weak and strong basic sites, respectively) which implied that the catalyst has the highest basicity due to the influence of NaOH treatment at the synthesis stage. When the catalyst was calcined at higher temperature, i.e. Ni/BTK-800, the amount of CO2 adsorbed was reduced by ˜52%. This loss of number of basic sites as calcination temperature increased was ascribed to dihydroxylation [45] of the SOD zeolitic structure as explained by a previous study which showed a major weight loss at high temperature between 750 and 800 °C in a thermal gravimetric analysis [21]. Interestingly, as calcination temperature increases from 700 to 800 °C, the desorption peak shifted from 168 and 689 °C to 362 and 726 °C signifying increased in basic strength density from weak-strong to medium-very strong in Ni/BTK-700 and Ni/BTK-800, respectively due to aggregation of the left over basic sites. Typically, as the thermal treatment progresses, water and nitrate anions (from Ni precursor) are released during the thermal treatment and as a result, medium–strong Lewis basic O2− – Ni2+ pairs and strong basic sites linked to isolated O2− ions are produced that can operate as active base sites. This loss of basicity due to thermal initiated dehydroxylation is only well pronounced at weak and medium basic sites. For the NiOx/BTK-800, the number of basic sites was reduced by ˜66% (relative to Ni/BTK-700, Table S2) but increase in strong basic strength from 689 to 779 °C due to the combined influence of higher calcination temperature and weak protonation from the oxalic acid used for functionalization that removed the medium basic site (Peak 2) that was earlier seen in Ni/BTK-700 at 282 °C. There is conspicuous loss of basic sites with considerable reduction in strong basic strength for NiOx/ATK-800 due to obvious reasons, i.e., acid activation of the support. 3.2 Catalytic activities The activities of the synthesized catalyst are shown Fig. 9 . In all the catalyst tested, the CH4 conversion is lower that the CO2 conversion due to the theoretical higher CH bond activation energy (410 kJ/mol @ 4 = 1640 kJ/mol) which is higher than the CO bond energy (799 kJ/mol @ 2 = 1598 kJ/mol) and possibly the occurrence of reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction (CO + H₂O ⇌ CO₂ + H₂) as side reaction [46]. The general trend in these results showed that OxL functionalized catalysts are more active showing higher reaction rates for both CH4 and CO2, as well as higher yield of the syngas with higher H2/CO ratio. For example, the rate of reaction on Ni/BTK-800 and NiOx/BTK-800 were 3.80 and 6.55 mol CO2 ∙ mol Ni −1 ∙ s−1, and 2.47 and 5.33 mol CH4 ∙ mol Ni −1 ∙ s−1, respectively, which implied the OxLF approximately doubled the activity. This is well supported by the XPS and TEM results and it is in accordance with a previous report on surface organometallic chemistry to prepare Ni nanoparticles supported on alumina [6]. Similarly, higher calcination temperature does not favor the conversion of CH4 and CO2 gases and the yield of the syngas product, except for Ni/ATK-800 and NiOx/BTK-800 that does not show clear difference. When the results in Fig. 9 were normalized with the TEM, XRD and the TPR result, it follows that the average Ni particle size is a strong factor that influences the activity of the catalyst. This is also in consonance with the TPD-CO2 profile which established that higher basicity correlates positively with lower Ni particle sizes with attendant increase in metal dispersion which are both beneficial for the DMR as mentioned previously. Although it appear that there is a conflict in this trend for Ni/BTK-800 and NiOx/BTK-800 catalysts, in that the former showed higher basicity than the latter, but the activity of the latter still supersedes in Fig. 9. This can be explained from the XRF and XPS results. According to the XRF result, the amount of Ni species is higher in NiOx/BTK-800 than Ni/BTK-800 (Table 1), thus leading to higher number of active sites. Furthermore, the XPS result showed that the Ni species exhibits weaker metal-support-interaction (MSI) in NiOx/BTK-800 than in Ni/BTK-800 as can be seen in the relative shift of the Ni 2p3/2 towards lower binding energy. This phenomenon in turn guarantees highly reducible nano Ni particles with good dispersion after reduction due to the OxLF. The OxLF is so effective that the reaction rate of Ni/ATK-700 (Fig. 9) which was the lowest of all the tested catalysts due to the influence of acid treatment on RK and very large Ni particle sizes was doubled in NiOx/ATK-700, showing superior activity to even Ni/BTK-700 that was activated with NaOH which ordinarily is expected to enhance at least CO2 conversion. 3.3 catalyst stability The result of stability of the catalysts studied over 20 h time on stream (TOS) are shown in Fig. 10 , and the percent activity loss was summarized in Figure S4. Amongst all the tested catalysts, NiOx/BTK-700 showed the highest stability with 10.1% and 7.3% activity loss in CH4 and CO2, respectively, followed by Ni/BTK-700 with 22.7% and 18.4% activity loss in CH4 and CO2, respectively after 20 h TOS. This implied that the activity loss is more pronounced towards CH4 activation due to the higher CH bond activation energy previously mentioned. The catalysts that were calcined at 800 °C all showed poor stability which were ascribed to their relatively larger average particle size (see Table 2). According to literature [46], carbon formation increases with increase in average Ni particles, therefore when sintering occurs during the reaction it enhances carbon deposition. Thus, this implied that sintering has a double effect on the catalyst activity; firstly, the active surface decreases leading to reduction in the catalytic activity and secondly carbon formation is more favored on bigger particles leading to a faster deactivation of the catalyst. Besides the direct Ni particle sizes effect, the modified support morphology also plays significant role. Generally, the BTK supported catalysts exhibited better stabilities than the ATK supported catalysts, and we ascribed this to the NaOH treatment of RK that resulted into surface and structural reconstruction of the BTK support into SOD zeolite (see SEM and XRD results) which resulted into Ni nanoparticles with very strong MSI (according to the H2-TPR peaks and XPS results) that can resist sintering tendency. It is not surprising that Ni/ATK-700 with lower DMR activity does not suffers higher activity loss (unlike its OXLF analogue - NiOx/ATK-700) since its rate of reaction is low leading to low deactivation. Conversely, the high deactivation over its high calcination temperature analog - Ni/ATK-800 - was due to the large Ni particle size sintering. Ironically, NiOx/ATK-700 showed the poorest stability and it was ascribed to two reasons: 1. the influence of OXLF which resulted into comparably weaker MSI, thus the weakly bonded Ni particles can easily agglomerate under DMR reaction. 2. Relatively lower calcination temperature, since H2-TPR and XPS results and previous report [47] have shown that higher calcination temperature provides stronger MSI. The combination of these two phenomena resulted into increase in Ni particles sizes with attendant carbon deposition as seen in the TEM image of NiOx/ATK-700 in Figure S5 which compares the structure/morphology before and after use at 20 h TOS. On the overall, the activity and stability of NiOx/BTK-700 and Ni/BTK-700 are promising more so that the Ni particles were not promoted by any other metals such as Sn, Ce, Mg, MgO, BaO etc as usually found in the literature [6,9]. For example, Saché et al. [46], reported an average of 50% and 36% activity loss for CH4 and CO2 over a series of Ni/CeAl and Ni-Sn/CeAl catalysts. Furthermore, their results showed that Sn promoted catalyst suffers little deactivation, whereas for the base catalyst - Ni/CeAl, deactivation occurs quickly. Similarly, they showed that CeO2 promotes the reverse RWGS even at high temperatures. 4 Conclusion The possibility of employing natural occuring raw kaolin clay minerals (RK) as catalysts support for dry methane reforming (DMR) has been demonstrated in this report. Since the in situ RK is not active for use as catallyst support, the influence of acid and base activation of RK was studied as well as the influence of functionalizing the Ni active metal precursor with oxalate ligand (OxL). The synthesized catalyst were calcined at 700 and 800 °C. The results showed that acid activation produced samples with increase in Sl/Al ratio with transformed morphology from stacked layered sheets to disaggregated and disordered arrangement with increased porosity, while base treatment transform the RK into zeolitic material. Futhermore, the results showed that there is a strong correlation between the Ni particles sizes, degree of dispersion and yield of H2 and CO from DMR process. Generally, base activated catalysts showed higher basicity according to TPD−CO2 and higher reactant consumption leading to higher product yields. Higher calcination at 800 °C does not favour the yield of the desired products due to Ni particles agglomeration at higher calcniation temperature. Irrespective of the catalysts calination temprature and acid or base activation, the OxL functionalized catalysts showed the smallest particle size, highest dispersion and reducibility leading to superior rate of reaction and yield of H2 and CO as well as better catalytic stability. Thus, functionalization of active Ni with OxL, comparably lower calcination and catalyst basicity are favorable to DMR. coredata.dc:description: Kaolinite, the main mineral in raw kaolin clay (RK) was explored as catalyst support for dry methane reforming (DMR) to produce syngas. Due to the inactiveness of the RK, it was activated by 5 M HCl and 5 M NaOH to produce acid treated kaolinite (ATK) and base treated kaolinite (BTK) catalyst supports, respectively. Two types of Ni active metal was incorporated into the modified supports, the first was the conventional nickel nitrate salt, and the second, organometallic nickel precursor synthesized via oxalate ligand functionalization (OxLF) of nickel particles. All the synthesized catalysts were calcined at 700 or 800 °C to study the effect of thermal treatment. The characterization results showed that OxLF was able to restrict the loss of Ni during washing and filtering at the synthesis stage according to the XRF result. The BTK support summarily transformed into SOD zeolite. Furthermore, the BTK supported catalyst showed comparable higher basicity than the ATK supported, however, as calcination temperature increases, there is loss of basic sites in both ATK and BTK supported catalysts, increase in the Ni mean particle sizes, and decrease in the Ni dispersion which cumulatively reduced the reaction rates leading to lower syngas yield. Irrespective of the catalyst support type and the calcination temperature, the oxalate ligand functionalized catalyst showed the lowest Ni mean particle sizes, highest metal dispersion and their Ni2p3/2 peaks were observed to shift towards lower binding energy according to the XPS results signifying higher reducibility which was verified by H2-TPR. The most efficient catalysts was NiOx/BTK-700 with 21.85% and 28.49% yield of H2 and CO, respectively. It also has the highest activity stability after 20 h TOS. The results showed that kaolinite is a possible future catalyst support for DMR.
coredata.dc:title: Exploring kaolinite as dry methane reforming catalyst support: Influences of chemical activation, organic ligand functionalization and calcination temperature
